ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned how to write in a scientific chemistry style
I learned a lot of lab skills and how to test for compounds.
Through this course, I built on the techniques learned in Lab for Organic Chemistry II, and learned new techniques for analyzing sample identity including NMR Spectroscopy.
I learned how to analyze and write about scientific data. I learned about the techniques of obtaining that data as well as how to construct, research, and compose scientific reports.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Both the professor and TA were very unclear about what the assignments entailed. Sometimes they would separately provide two different sets of expectations for the assignment. Every assignment guideline was just whatever they would say in class. You could very much tell that the TA and the prof didnt communicate well with each other. 

The grading was also very weird. There were no rubrics and it seemed that they just took off points for whatever they wanted. They also provided feedback really late. Mistakes wouldve been repeated multiple times because the feedback was provided so late.

They provided resources as a basis for assignments, but then they would take off points for following that resource. In class the next day, they would discuss a structure they had never mentioned before (that didnt align with the provided resources) and elaborate on how they had expected this format.

There were a lot of unsaid expectations of the assignments that were not communicated to us, the students.
Strengths- quizzes were fair. Weaknesses- workload was extremely high and I dont think I would be very confident in an in person chem lab.
I thought this course was very well done.

Strengths: The recordings of lectures and uploaded sample data removed the stress of preparing for a 4-5 hour in-person lab and allowed me to focus more on the theory and analysis components of the lab. I also found the regular/consistent deadlines for EPs/LNs/PLs to be helpful. 

Weaknesses: Given that this is a practical lab course, I found the virtual format to be somewhat compromised. It was very difficult to develop proficiency with the techniques and gain experience in a lab setting merely by watching videos.

This course was thorough and demanding in terms of the writing component. However, it was not very organized. Every post lab was announced during lab, allowing for little planning ahead if we wanted to work ahead, and many were not graded fast enough to be able to know what to change for the next post labs. Nevertheless, the teaching staff was approachable and helpful.

The expectations for assignments were often extremely unclear, and the grading did not align with the resources posted on Canvas. We would then lose a very large proportion of the points on the assignment due to small errors made. Furthermore, we would get feedback extremely late for some assignments and as a result have already turned in other similar assignments, and thus made the same mistakes on both assignments and lost points for the same item. We would also have one error marked on one assignment but did not receive feedback on the same error made on a previous assignment. This was extremely frustrating and there was a distinct lack of clear communication of expectations.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you have to for your major
Yes it was very interesting.
I would recommend that a student takes the in-person, semester-long version of this class. It is very difficult to replicate the in-person experience in a virtual format.

I would recommend taking this in the summer because it is helpful to get it out of the way if it is a requirement. The chemical basis for the experiments is very interesting. However, two labs a week means the workload is very high and (especially if you are taking lecture at the same time), can be difficult to manage at times.
No, because of the aforementioned issues.

narratives.question_text: The Canvas course site allowed me to identify and access required course materials easily.
comments: Agree

Agree
